title: Learn Service Layer Principles Unit | Salesforce Trailhead

questions.title: 1Which of the following Service method signatures comply with the design goals of the Service layer?

answers.content: B void ThingsService.handleTabOut(String event, Map<String, String> fieldData)

questions.title: 2Which of the following is the responsibility of the Service layer?

answers.content: A Handling all errors so that the callers can get on with their lives in blissful ignorance.
C Being the picture of bulkification perfection and accepting a list of things to do.
D Exposing a number of fine-grained service methods so that callers can piece together their own high-level services.

wrongAnswers.content: B Leaving it up to the callers to figure out when to use SavePoints to avoid partial commits to the database.

correctAnswer.content: C Being the picture of bulkification perfection and accepting a list of things to do.

questions.title: 3Which of the following describes the best places to put your Apex logic while keeping in mind SOC and the Service layer on Force.com?

answers.content: A Visualforce and Lightning pages follow the MVC pattern, so it's fine to place calculations and validation code in Controller classes and occasionally in an Apex Trigger if there is a likelihood that someone wants to bulk-load into your objects.

B Controllers, Batch Apex, Email Handlers, Queueables, and other ways to execute Apex on the platform should all delegate to a shared Service layer. The concern of such callers is primarily to integrate with the platform or UI and then to pass on responsibility to a service that is designed to encapsulate application business logic, be scalable, and caller agnostic.
C Since Force.com is object based it is best to focus all your logic in the Apex Trigger layer and keep as little as possible logic in other classes.

D Logic relating to the calculations that occur when records are manipulated should be kept away from your objects and stored in utility classes or controller methods. Only validation logic or defaulting logic should be included in the Apex Trigger layer.

correctAnswer.content: B Controllers, Batch Apex, Email Handlers, Queueables, and other ways to execute Apex on the platform should all delegate to a shared Service layer. The concern of such callers is primarily to integrate with the platform or UI and then to pass on responsibility to a service that is designed to encapsulate application business logic, be scalable, and caller agnostic.

questions.title: 4Where do you apply the with sharing keyword?

wrongAnswers.content: B On every class the Service class calls
D Nowhere; the caller of the Service determines this
